title: Impossible case reached: src/librustc_ty/needs_drop.rs:111

labels.name: E-easy
labels.description: Call for participation: Experience needed to fix: Easy / not much (good first issue)

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: E-help-wanted
labels.description: Call for participation: Help is requested to fix this issue.

labels.name: AsyncAwait-Triaged
labels.description: Async-await issues that have been triaged during a working group meeting.

labels.name: E-needs-mcve
labels.description: Call for participation: This issue needs a Minimal Complete and Verifiable Example

body:
I can't share the code, but I have a commit at which problem surfaced in case I need to check it again.


With rustc 1.45.0-nightly (664fcd3f0 2020-05-27):

```log
error: internal compiler error: src/librustc_ty/needs_drop.rs:110: impossible case reached

thread 'rustc' panicked at 'Box<Any>', src/librustc_errors/lib.rs:907:9
stack backtrace:

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.

note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports

note: rustc 1.45.0-nightly (664fcd3f0 2020-05-27) running on x86_64-apple-darwin

note: compiler flags: -C panic=abort -C embed-bitcode=no -C debuginfo=2 -C incremental --crate-type lib

note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden

query stack during panic:
#0 [needs_drop_raw] computing whether `std::future::from_generator::GenFuture<[static generator@src/peer/coordinator.rs:129:21: 161:2 ctx:[type error], stream:[type error], buf:[type error], peers:[type error], server:[type error] [type error]]>` needs drop
#1 [optimized_mir] processing `peer::coordinator::relay::{{closure}}#0`
end of query stack
error: aborting due to previous error

error: could not compile `MY_CRATE`.

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```
